Award.AwardTitle: A Conference on Analysis and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support to defray expenses of participants to attend a conference on analysis and its applications during May 16-20, 2011 at Princeton University.

This major conference will include lectures by world leaders in Harmonic Analysis, Several Complex Variables, Partial Differential Equations, and Geometric Analysis. The conference will also emphasize the interaction of Analysis with Combinatorics, Number Theory, and Theoretical Computer Science. All of these areas were significantly impacted by the research and teaching of Elias Stein, and the conference is being organized in honor of his influence.

The conference will allow participants, as well as others in the mathematical community, to learn about recent progress on a broad range of subjects in Analysis. The organizers will invite graduate students, young postdocs, women and minority researchers to participate actively in the conference. In addition to the plenary lectures, the conference will include a panel discussion on teaching Mathematics, collaboration in Mathematics, and the writing of Mathematics books.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ANALYSIS AND APPLICATIONS: A CONFERENCE IN HONOR OF
ELIAS STEIN


PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT FOR NSF GRANT DMS-1101562


     The conference “Analysis and Applications: a Conference in Honor of Elias Stein” took place in Princeton, NJ, between Monday, May 16, and Friday, May 20, 2011. The conference focused on modern developments in Analysis, many of them pioneered by Elias Stein, and their many applications to other fields, such as Partial Differential Equations, Analysis in Several Complex Variables, Geometric Analysis, and Analytic Number Theory.

     The scientific program of the conference consisted of 24 plenary lectures, delivered by leading experts in the field, and 1 panel discussion. The panel discussion was a discussion on teaching and learning Mathematics, aimed at young researchers.


     The conference was supported by grants from the National Science Foundation, the Clay Mathematics Institute, the American Institute of Mathematics, and the Princeton University Mathematics Department. Most of the NSF funds were used to support the participation of young researchers (graduate students, postdocs, and assistant professors).


     More information about the conference, including videos of the lectures, can be found on the website of the conference:  http://www.math.princeton.edu/conference/stein2011/. The organizers plan to publish a Conference Proceedings, and most of the speakers have agreed to contribute a paper for these proceedings.
